title: How to Cook a Turkey Breast

methods.name: Defrosting and Seasoning the Turkey Breast

steps.headline: Purchase 1 ⁄4 pounds (570 g) of turkey breast for each person you'd like to serve.
steps.description: If there aren't fresh turkey breasts for sale in the meat case, check the meat department's freezer case. You should be able to buy bone-in skin-on breasts all year long. If you're serving 2 to 4 people, look for a turkey breast that's about 3 pounds (1.4 kg). To serve 6 to 8 people, buy a 6 to 7 lb (2.7 to 3.2 kg) turkey breast.

steps.headline: Thaw the turkey breast in the refrigerator for 1 day.
steps.description: At least 24 hours before you're ready to cook the turkey breast, leave it in its packaging and transfer it from the freezer to the bottom shelf of your refrigerator. Once the turkey is thawed, you can store it in the refrigerator for up to 2 days before you cook it. If you bought a fresh turkey breast, you can skip this step.

steps.headline: Remove the packaging and pat the turkey breast dry.
steps.description: Cut open the turkey's packaging and discard it. Then, set the turkey breast in a roasting pan or large plate and pat it dry with a paper towel. Don’t rinse the turkey breast, because this can spread bacteria through your kitchen.

steps.headline: Rub butter and seasoning over the turkey breast.
steps.description: Use your fingers to massage 1 tablespoon (14 g) of softened butter or extra-virgin olive oil over and under the turkey's skin. Then, sprinkle the entire turkey breast with 1 tablespoon (18 g) of kosher salt and 1/2 teaspoon (1 g) of ground black pepper.Lemon Garlic Variation: Blend the zest of 1 lemon with 1 shallot, 2 cloves of garlic, 3 tablespoons (44 ml) of olive oil, 1 teaspoon (2 g) of dried thyme, 1 teaspoon (5 g) of salt, and 1/2 teaspoon (1 g) of ground pepper. Then, spread it over the turkey breast. You can also scatter 2 teaspoons (4 g) of your choice of dried herbs, such as rosemary, oregano, or sage, over the turkey breast.

methods.name: Roasting the Turkey Breast in the Oven

steps.headline: Preheat the oven to 450 °F (232 °C) and adjust the oven racks.
steps.description: Move an oven rack to the bottom third of the oven. You'll probably need to move the middle rack higher in your oven or remove it so the turkey breast fits. If you remove an oven rack, set it aside until you're finished roasting the turkey breast. Preheating the oven to a higher temperature than you cook the turkey at will help its skin crisp.

steps.headline: Turn the temperature to 350 °F (177 °C) and bake the turkey for 25 to 30 minutes per 1 pound (0.45 kg).
steps.description: Place the roasting pan with the turkey breast on the lower rack and keep the turkey breast uncovered as it bakes.Tip: Plan on roasting the turkey breast for about 25 to 30 minutes per 1 pound (0.45 kg). Your turkey breast may take longer to cook depending on the size of your turkey. If the turkey breast is becoming too brown, cover it loosely with aluminum foil.

steps.headline: Check the turkey breast to see if it's reached 165 °F (74 °C).
steps.description: Insert an instant-read meat thermometer into the thickest part of the breast. The turkey is finished cooking once it's at least 165 °F (74 °C). If the turkey isn't at 165 °F (74 °C) yet, put it back in the oven and bake it for 15 more minutes before you check again.

steps.headline: Remove the turkey breast and let it rest for 20 minutes.
steps.description: Set the turkey on a carving board and cover it with aluminum foil. Then, let the turkey breast rest so the juices redistribute within the meat. You can make gravy while the turkey rests.

steps.headline: Carve the turkey breast and serve it with your favorite sides.
steps.description: Since carving a turkey breast is easier than carving an entire turkey, all you need to do is use a chef's knife to slice back and forth along one side of the breastbone until you reach the center. Then, carve the other breast and serve the turkey with mashed potatoes, green beans, and stuffing, for instance. If you have leftovers, refrigerate them in an airtight container for up to 4 days.

steps.headline: Arrange the turkey breast in the slow cooker.
steps.description: You can put chopped vegetables in the bottom of the slow cooker if you'd like to add extra flavor or have vegetables to serve with the turkey breast. Then, place the turkey breast on top.Tip: For roasted vegetables, you could scatter 3 chopped potatoes and 6 or 7 chopped carrots in the cooker along with 1 chopped onion. If you just want to flavor the turkey and create juices for gravy, slice 1 or 2 onions and lay them on the bottom of the slow cooker.

steps.headline: Cook the turkey breast for 7 to 8 hours on "Low."
steps.description: Cover the slow cooker and don't lift off the lid while the turkey breast cooks. If you remove the lid, the temperature inside the cooker will drop significantly, which will make your turkey breast take longer to cook. If you'd like to cook the turkey on "High," check the turkey after it's cooked for 4 or 5 hours.

steps.headline: Remove the turkey breast once it reaches 165 °F (74 °C).
steps.description: Once you think the turkey breast has finished cooking, stick an instant-read meat thermometer into the thickest part of the breast. If the turkey hasn't reached 165 °F (74 °C), cook it for another 15 to 20 minutes before you check it again. If you'd like to use a boneless turkey breast, keep in mind that it will cook a little faster than a bone-in turkey breast.

steps.headline: Broil the turkey breast on a roasting sheet for 5 minutes.
steps.description: If you'd like your turkey to have crispy skin, place it on a roasting sheet and put it about 3 inches (7.6 cm) below the broiler. Broil the turkey breast until the skin becomes browned and crispy. If you don't mind that the skin is pale, you can skip this step.

steps.headline: Rest the turkey for 20 minutes before you serve it.
steps.description: Lay a piece of aluminum foil loosely over the breast and rest the turkey so the juices redistribute within the meat. Then, use a sharp knife to carefully carve the turkey breast into ⁄4 to ⁄2 inch (0.64 to 1.27 cm) thick slices. Then, serve the turkey with any vegetables you cooked alongside it. Refrigerate leftover turkey in an airtight container for up to 4 days.

tyn: Defrosting and Seasoning the Turkey Breast
Roasting the Turkey Breast in the Oven
text: Defrosting and Seasoning the Turkey Breast Purchase 1 ⁄4 pounds (570 g) of turkey breast for each person you'd like to serve. If there aren't fresh turkey breasts for sale in the meat case, check the meat department's freezer case. You should be able to buy bone-in skin-on breasts all year long. If you're serving 2 to 4 people, look for a turkey breast that's about 3 pounds (1.4 kg). To serve 6 to 8 people, buy a 6 to 7 lb (2.7 to 3.2 kg) turkey breast. Thaw the turkey breast in the refrigerator for 1 day. At least 24 hours before you're ready to cook the turkey breast, leave it in its packaging and transfer it from the freezer to the bottom shelf of your refrigerator. Once the turkey is thawed, you can store it in the refrigerator for up to 2 days before you cook it. If you bought a fresh turkey breast, you can skip this step. Remove the packaging and pat the turkey breast dry. Cut open the turkey's packaging and discard it. Then, set the turkey breast in a roasting pan or large plate and pat it dry with a paper towel. Don’t rinse the turkey breast, because this can spread bacteria through your kitchen. Rub butter and seasoning over the turkey breast. Use your fingers to massage 1 tablespoon (14 g) of softened butter or extra-virgin olive oil over and under the turkey's skin. Then, sprinkle the entire turkey breast with 1 tablespoon (18 g) of kosher salt and 1/2 teaspoon (1 g) of ground black pepper.Lemon Garlic Variation: Blend the zest of 1 lemon with 1 shallot, 2 cloves of garlic, 3 tablespoons (44 ml) of olive oil, 1 teaspoon (2 g) of dried thyme, 1 teaspoon (5 g) of salt, and 1/2 teaspoon (1 g) of ground pepper. Then, spread it over the turkey breast. You can also scatter 2 teaspoons (4 g) of your choice of dried herbs, such as rosemary, oregano, or sage, over the turkey breast. Roasting the Turkey Breast in the Oven Preheat the oven to 450 °F (232 °C) and adjust the oven racks. Move an oven rack to the bottom third of the oven. You'll probably need to move the middle rack higher in your oven or remove it so the turkey breast fits. If you remove an oven rack, set it aside until you're finished roasting the turkey breast. Preheating the oven to a higher temperature than you cook the turkey at will help its skin crisp. Turn the temperature to 350 °F (177 °C) and bake the turkey for 25 to 30 minutes per 1 pound (0.45 kg). Place the roasting pan with the turkey breast on the lower rack and keep the turkey breast uncovered as it bakes.Tip: Plan on roasting the turkey breast for about 25 to 30 minutes per 1 pound (0.45 kg). Your turkey breast may take longer to cook depending on the size of your turkey. If the turkey breast is becoming too brown, cover it loosely with aluminum foil. Check the turkey breast to see if it's reached 165 °F (74 °C). Insert an instant-read meat thermometer into the thickest part of the breast. The turkey is finished cooking once it's at least 165 °F (74 °C). If the turkey isn't at 165 °F (74 °C) yet, put it back in the oven and bake it for 15 more minutes before you check again. Remove the turkey breast and let it rest for 20 minutes. Set the turkey on a carving board and cover it with aluminum foil. Then, let the turkey breast rest so the juices redistribute within the meat. You can make gravy while the turkey rests. Carve the turkey breast and serve it with your favorite sides. Since carving a turkey breast is easier than carving an entire turkey, all you need to do is use a chef's knife to slice back and forth along one side of the breastbone until you reach the center. Then, carve the other breast and serve the turkey with mashed potatoes, green beans, and stuffing, for instance. If you have leftovers, refrigerate them in an airtight container for up to 4 days. Slow-Cooking the Turkey Breast Arrange the turkey breast in the slow cooker. You can put chopped vegetables in the bottom of the slow cooker if you'd like to add extra flavor or have vegetables to serve with the turkey breast. Then, place the turkey breast on top.Tip: For roasted vegetables, you could scatter 3 chopped potatoes and 6 or 7 chopped carrots in the cooker along with 1 chopped onion. If you just want to flavor the turkey and create juices for gravy, slice 1 or 2 onions and lay them on the bottom of the slow cooker. Cook the turkey breast for 7 to 8 hours on "Low." Cover the slow cooker and don't lift off the lid while the turkey breast cooks. If you remove the lid, the temperature inside the cooker will drop significantly, which will make your turkey breast take longer to cook. If you'd like to cook the turkey on "High," check the turkey after it's cooked for 4 or 5 hours. Remove the turkey breast once it reaches 165 °F (74 °C). Once you think the turkey breast has finished cooking, stick an instant-read meat thermometer into the thickest part of the breast. If the turkey hasn't reached 165 °F (74 °C), cook it for another 15 to 20 minutes before you check it again. If you'd like to use a boneless turkey breast, keep in mind that it will cook a little faster than a bone-in turkey breast. Broil the turkey breast on a roasting sheet for 5 minutes. If you'd like your turkey to have crispy skin, place it on a roasting sheet and put it about 3 inches (7.6 cm) below the broiler. Broil the turkey breast until the skin becomes browned and crispy. If you don't mind that the skin is pale, you can skip this step. Rest the turkey for 20 minutes before you serve it. Lay a piece of aluminum foil loosely over the breast and rest the turkey so the juices redistribute within the meat. Then, use a sharp knife to carefully carve the turkey breast into ⁄4 to ⁄2 inch (0.64 to 1.27 cm) thick slices. Then, serve the turkey with any vegetables you cooked alongside it. Refrigerate leftover turkey in an airtight container for up to 4 days.
sentences: Defrosting and Seasoning the Turkey Breast Purchase 1 ⁄4 pounds (570 g) of turkey breast for each person you'd like to serve.
If there aren't fresh turkey breasts for sale in the meat case, check the meat department's freezer case.
You should be able to buy bone-in skin-on breasts all year long.
If you're serving 2 to 4 people, look for a turkey breast that's about 3 pounds (1.4 kg).
To serve 6 to 8 people, buy a 6 to 7 lb (2.7 to 3.2 kg) turkey breast.
Thaw the turkey breast in the refrigerator for 1 day.
At least 24 hours before you're ready to cook the turkey breast, leave it in its packaging and transfer it from the freezer to the bottom shelf of your refrigerator.
Once the turkey is thawed, you can store it in the refrigerator for up to 2 days before you cook it.
If you bought a fresh turkey breast, you can skip this step.
Remove the packaging and pat the turkey breast dry.
Cut open the turkey's packaging and discard it.
Then, set the turkey breast in a roasting pan or large plate and pat it dry with a paper towel.
Don’t rinse the turkey breast, because this can spread bacteria through your kitchen.
Rub butter and seasoning over the turkey breast.
Use your fingers to massage 1 tablespoon (14 g) of softened butter or extra-virgin olive oil over and under the turkey's skin.

Then, sprinkle the entire turkey breast with 1 tablespoon (18 g) of kosher salt and 1/2 teaspoon (1 g) of ground black pepper.Lemon Garlic Variation: Blend the zest of 1 lemon with 1 shallot, 2 cloves of garlic, 3 tablespoons (44 ml) of olive oil, 1 teaspoon (2 g) of dried thyme, 1 teaspoon (5 g) of salt, and 1/2 teaspoon (1 g) of ground pepper.
Then, spread it over the turkey breast.
You can also scatter 2 teaspoons (4 g) of your choice of dried herbs, such as rosemary, oregano, or sage, over the turkey breast.
Roasting the Turkey Breast in the Oven Preheat the oven to 450 °F (232 °C) and adjust the oven racks.
Move an oven rack to the bottom third of the oven.
You'll probably need to move the middle rack higher in your oven or remove it so the turkey breast fits.
If you remove an oven rack, set it aside until you're finished roasting the turkey breast.
Preheating the oven to a higher temperature than you cook the turkey at will help its skin crisp.
Turn the temperature to 350 °F (177 °C) and bake the turkey for 25 to 30 minutes per 1 pound (0.45 kg).

Place the roasting pan with the turkey breast on the lower rack and keep the turkey breast uncovered as it bakes.Tip: Plan on roasting the turkey breast for about 25 to 30 minutes per 1 pound (0.45 kg).
Your turkey breast may take longer to cook depending on the size of your turkey.
If the turkey breast is becoming too brown, cover it loosely with aluminum foil.
Check the turkey breast to see if it's reached 165 °F (74 °C).
Insert an instant-read meat thermometer into the thickest part of the breast.
The turkey is finished cooking once it's at least 165 °F (74 °C).
If the turkey isn't at 165 °F (74 °C) yet, put it back in the oven and bake it for 15 more minutes before you check again.
Remove the turkey breast and let it rest for 20 minutes.
Set the turkey on a carving board and cover it with aluminum foil.
Then, let the turkey breast rest so the juices redistribute within the meat.
You can make gravy while the turkey rests.
Carve the turkey breast and serve it with your favorite sides.
Since carving a turkey breast is easier than carving an entire turkey, all you need to do is use a chef's knife to slice back and forth along one side of the breastbone until you reach the center.
Then, carve the other breast and serve the turkey with mashed potatoes, green beans, and stuffing, for instance.
If you have leftovers, refrigerate them in an airtight container for up to 4 days.
Slow-Cooking the Turkey Breast Arrange the turkey breast in the slow cooker.
You can put chopped vegetables in the bottom of the slow cooker if you'd like to add extra flavor or have vegetables to serve with the turkey breast.
Then, place the turkey breast on top.Tip: For roasted vegetables, you could scatter 3 chopped potatoes and 6 or 7 chopped carrots in the cooker along with 1 chopped onion.
If you just want to flavor the turkey and create juices for gravy, slice 1 or 2 onions and lay them on the bottom of the slow cooker.
Cook the turkey breast for 7 to 8 hours on "Low."
Cover the slow cooker and don't lift off the lid while the turkey breast cooks.
If you remove the lid, the temperature inside the cooker will drop significantly, which will make your turkey breast take longer to cook.
If you'd like to cook the turkey on "High," check the turkey after it's cooked for 4 or 5 hours.
Remove the turkey breast once it reaches 165 °F (74 °C).
Once you think the turkey breast has finished cooking, stick an instant-read meat thermometer into the thickest part of the breast.
If the turkey hasn't reached 165 °F (74 °C), cook it for another 15 to 20 minutes before you check it again.
If you'd like to use a boneless turkey breast, keep in mind that it will cook a little faster than a bone-in turkey breast.
Broil the turkey breast on a roasting sheet for 5 minutes.
If you'd like your turkey to have crispy skin, place it on a roasting sheet and put it about 3 inches (7.6 cm) below the broiler.
Broil the turkey breast until the skin becomes browned and crispy.
If you don't mind that the skin is pale, you can skip this step.
Rest the turkey for 20 minutes before you serve it.
Lay a piece of aluminum foil loosely over the breast and rest the turkey so the juices redistribute within the meat.
Then, use a sharp knife to carefully carve the turkey breast into ⁄4 to ⁄2 inch (0.64 to 1.27 cm) thick slices.
Then, serve the turkey with any vegetables you cooked alongside it.
Refrigerate leftover turkey in an airtight container for up to 4 days.
